The South masses its forces under charismatic Albert Sidney Johnston to strike Union troops encamped at Pittsburgh Landing, on the Tennessee River. These forces are commanded by the North's newest war hero: Ulysses S. Grant.

April's Harvest covers the resulting Battle of Shiloh, the largest bloodbath to that point on the North American continent. The game portrays the whole battle, from the initial Rebel drive through the camps of the surprised Union army, to the Grant's final counterstroke after receiving desperately needed reinforcements.

Special features cover the fighting at the Hornet's Nest, the uncertain arrival of Buell's Army of the Ohio, Union gunboats and Confederate looting. A host of options allow players to see how Shiloh might have been fought if Grant hadn't been surprised, or if the South had received additional men from Van Dorn's Army of the West

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 30 minutes
Hex: 200 yards
Units: Brigades

Game Inventory:
One 22 x 34" full-color mapsheet
One dual-side printed countersheet (280 1/2" counters)
One 32-page CWBS 2nd Edition system rulebook
One 24-page April's Harvest specific rulebook
Two 6-sided dice

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 1 or more
Playing Time: 4-20 hours
10964.name: April's Harvest: The Battle of Shiloh, April 6 & 7, 1862

10965.name: Word Spin
10965.description: 8 ten-sided discs have letters on each face; the consonants have points values. The discs are magnetic and hold together, allowing the player to quickly rotate the discs back and forth to make words. You can easily break the whole thing apart to re-arrange the discs for variety. Includes various rules for different word games.

10966.description:
Battle Rider is a stand alone scifi game, maps are compatible to Brilliant Lances.

From the box:
Battle Rider is the game of squadron and fleet combat in GDW´s Traveller universe.
Battle Rider gives you fast-moving fleet combat without the need for roleplaying levels of detail.
Interactive game turn sequences and hidden task force rules emphasize decision-making, tactics, and bluffing instead of game mechanics.
Unique diceless game system utilizes battle resolution cards for all sensor, evasion, and firing tasks.
10966.name: Battle Rider

boardgamefamily.7757: From RPG books to board games

10967.name: Slime Monster Game
10967.description:
From the rules: The Slime Monster has invaded the town. You've got to stop him! You must get from the High School to the Armory, pick up a land mine and knock the Slime Monster over. But be careful that the Slime monster doesn't knock you over with his slime.

Movement is directed with a spinner. Each spin is used twice: once for the player and the same amount for the monster. The players try to manipulate the monster so that he winds up standing over an opponent. He then "slimes" the player and moves. If the slime covering the player causes the player piece to fall over, the player must start again. Yuck!

10968.name: Crash Canyon
10968.description: This off road racing game uses a large three dimensional board very similar to Fireball Island. Players race their 4x4 vehicles with the roll of a special six sided die without a 1 pip but it has a star instead. Rolling a star allows you to move opponents cars and roll again. Cars can roll freely on the board and possibly roll off the board or crash. When movement ends, you must release your 4x4 and see if it "free wheels." Rolling off the board or crashing means the loss of a turn while you get your 4x4 back on the road. Seven boulders on the road (placed at the start of the game) stop movement, but are removed from the game when first encountered. Light hearted and fun, especially with younger players.

10969.name: Cold Feet
10969.description: The Squirt Game! A very unusual game that has a water gun attached to the game board. Spin the spinner on the game board and fire the water gun, but it only fires once or twice out of every six trigger pulls. Players start the game with 5 tokens. Trade in small water drip tokens to avoid getting shot and collect tokens when the trigger is pulled but does not fire. Tokens are small, medium and large sized plastic "water drops." Trade in 5 small tokens for a medium token. Trade in 2 medium tokens for a large token and win the game by trading in 2 large tokens for the "Big Shot" button. Just the game we want to play in a room filled with cardboard game boxes!

10970.name: Pot Luck
10970.description: Buying and selling of pot in a Monopoly-like game where you want bales of pot rather than Hotels. The game board and the "Bum Me Out" and "Far Out" cards have colorful cartoon art, but the Pot (property) cards have color photos of the different types of pot you can own. Simple game with little substance. Great for collectors of "contraband games," but doesn't get played very often.

10971.name: Board and Table Games from Many Civilizations

boardgameversion.36185: Dover Revised Edition: Two volumes bound as one

10971.description:
Anybody that has looked in the Games section in a bookshop will have seen this work. Originally published by the OUP in two volumes, Board And Table Games 1 (1960), Board And Table Games 2 (1969), the revised edition in 1979 brought both books together.

Robert Bell wrote the definitive scholastic text on pretty much every ancient abstract board, tile, race and dice game you've heard of, and more you never knew about. With simple illustrations and some b&w photos, the rules and history of each game is quickly and briefly studied. There are even biographies of noted gamers, such as Hoyle.

This is an academic work, for students not children, but even dipping into it will bring great pleasure to any gamer. And Bell constantly encourages the reader to make and play the games shown.

ISBN 0-486-23855-5

10972.description:
Fleet Action is a game concerning large struggles in the Babylon 5 Universe.

From the cover:
Fleet Action is a fast-paced game of starship combat on a fleet scale. No longer are you simply concerned with the actions of just one or two warships. Now you must guide the actions of three dozen at once.
10972.name: Fleet Action

10973.name: Dice Games Properly Explained
10973.description:
Reiner Knizia's paperback book about dice games runs to 224 pages including the index. There are 8 chapters:
1. Lucky Scoring Games
2. Lucky Counter Games
3. The Theory of Dice (9 pages headed "It's easier than you think")
4. Betting Games
5. Progression Games
6. Jeopardy Games
7. Category Games
8. Bluffing Games

There are tons of games here, all explained pretty simply, in an open, friendly style. Most have one or two pages and include variants, tactics and odds where applicable. The only illustrations are relevant but basic diagrams, nothing big enough to photocopy.

The front piece notes some games are original to Knizia, and these are the ones that are mentioned as "original" games in the book - games like Catego or Six Hundred.

10974.name: Vallée de la mort
10974.description:
from thr MGDG website:

By the beginning of 1954, both French and Viet Minh realized that the war in Indochina was nearing an end. Ho Chi Minh had requested cease-fire negotiations in Geneva, Switzerland, and the French government was looking for a way out that would give them peace with honor. Both sides felt that a "big win" on the battlefield would finally secure at the peace table what they had been unable to obtain in six and a half years of war.

The site of this battle would be near a village called, in Vietnamese, "Seat of the Border County Prefecture" located in a distant valley of north-western Vietnam near the Laotian border. The French high command, under General Henri Navarre, reasoned that such remote location could not be successfully attacked. General Vo Nguyen Giap thought the position was nearly impossible to defend. The siege of Dien Bien Phu would be the result.

Vallée de la mort is a simulation of this epic siege that ended the French colonial presence in Asia and marked the beginning of a 21-year struggle for national unification. The game is designed for 2 players, one taking the role of the French commander of the fortress complex at Dien Bien Phu, the other of General Giap commanding the Viet-Minh forces laying siege. The game and scenarios are small enough to be played solitaire, however.

10975.name: Tell the Time Snap

boardgameversion.254653: Green Board Game red background edition

10975.description: This unique deck of cards uses snaps and pairs to teach children various concepts of time. Features include a 24 hour clock, digital clock, roman clock face, a.m. and p.m., etc... Ages 4 and up

10976.name: Things That Crawl
10976.description: Players race to complete their animals by trading cards. Their are 15 animals to complete, each with three parts. Ages 4 and up

10977.name: Times Table Snap
10977.description: Time's Table Snap uses a unique deck of cards to teach children multiplication concepts through games of pairs and snaps. Great for children practicing their multiplication tables. Ages 6 and up

10978.name: The Dutch Revolt
10978.description:
from the MGDG website:

Early in the 16th Century, an accident of inheritance joined the Low Countries to the sprawling Habsburg Empire. The local governments disliked threats to their traditions of self-rule, and heavy taxes to support foreign wars. At the same time the Protestant Reformation, which was sweeping Europe, found ready acceptance among the affluent, literate Dutch. There was little enough to bind the independent-minded Dutch to the distant Habsburg possessions in Spain and Austria, but the devout Catholicism of the Emperors and their Inquisition now made war inevitable. When the rebellion commenced in 1566, neither side foresaw either the decades of bloody civil war or the formation of an independent Dutch State.

The Dutch Revolt is a simulation of this conflict. One player commands the Catholic forces of the Habsburg Empire under King Philip II of Spain. The other player commands the Dutch Protestant forces under William of Orange.

10979.name: Fraction Action
10979.description:
A unique deck of cards designed to teach the concept of fractions using snaps and pairs. Covers percentages, decimals, and other fraction concepts. Includes a self-checking guide. Ages 6 and up

Uses the basic rules of the card game of War (flip a card, highest wins - ties flip another card with the winner getting them all). Game is played until one player has all of the cards.

10980.name: Four Function Snap
10980.description: A unique card deck designed to teach children children basic math concepts using snaps and pairs. Covers addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, as well as a few square roots, squares, and cubes. Ages 7 and up

10981.name: Like It or Lump It
10981.description: All the players are dealt 5-8 cards, depending on the number of people playing. Each card lists a thing to which a person is likely to have some emotional response. The cards have things as varied as "hip hop," "the smell of oranges," "Brad Pitt," "scoring the winning point," and "breakfast in bed." One player is the Lumper. The other players must give the Lumper a card from their hand that they think he/she will like a lot. The Lumper then arranges the cards on a board, which has spaces for Like It (10 points), Thumbs Up (7 points) A-OK (5 points), Not Bad (3 points), So So (2 points), Whatever (1 point), and Lump It (negative 5 points). The players earn (or lose) points depending on where their card was placed. The role of Lumper moves to the left, and when everyone has been a Lumper a prescribed number of times, the game ends. The highest score wins.

10982.name: Arena
10982.description:
Taken from the publisher's website:

The cost of life is increasing every day, and you do not know what to do with the coins in your pockets? Then Arena is the game for you! All the matches in this particular Arena are fought using nothing but coins and some dexterity: the White player and the Black one, on their turn, grab one of the twenty coins available and drop it in the Arena, trying to cover their opponent's dots while protecting their owns. Each move can mess up the board, because you are not only challenging your friend, but also the force of gravity itself!

This game was available in the free web magazine GiocAreA OnLine (former partner of daVinci Editrice) as a promotional tool.

10983.name: Landwehr 1438
10983.description: Tactical, topological tile game. It's set in medieval Northern Germany where four merchants set off to sell their goods in other towns and have to discover the safest and shortest roads for themselves, thereby avoiding many obstacles and roughness.

10984.name: Pounce

boardgameversion.49673: American Greetings Leisure Life slipcover box edition

10984.description:
Two-player abstract played on an 8x8 grid. The basic pieces are tall columns belonging to either player. When a player jumps another player's column, he places one of his discs on it, claiming it for himself. Columns can change ownership repeatedly in this way. The winner is the first player to move his remaining columns into his opponent's home row.

"Can a game with sixteen pieces and simple rules provide the action of checkers and the strategy of chess? The answer is yes, if the game is Pounce, the game that takes minutes to learn--and years to master."

10985.name: Fortune's Colony
10985.description:
In the far off distant future, corporations vie for control of new worlds and the resources they comprise. Using five 8-sided dice printed with colorful icons, players vie to land explorers, miners, bases, and supply ships on a newly-discovered planet. Watch out, though - your opponent's dice can knock into yours, disrupting your carefully laid explorations!

You need to print and assemble the dice yourself. Paper is OK, but 110lb cardstock is better. Surprisingly, once folded and glued, the dice have a fair bit of weight to them - not enough to put someone's eye out, but enough for the game to be playable.

The commercial PDF also included a cut-n-assemble box to keep the components in once you've cut and folded. The free version does not.

10986.description:
Second volume in the Triumph & Glory series covers the classic battle of Borodino. "The brigade-level Orders of Battle include the latest research, some directly from Russia (The Wonders of The Net!), and we even give the French player an opportunity - fraught with danger, to be sure - to attempt to undertake Davout's suggested flanking maneuver. In addition to the full Borodino, the game also includes a nice, short, 'introductory' mini-battle, the Attack on the Schevardino Redoubt (which took place 2 days before the actual battle)." [From box.]

SYSTEM: Triumph & Glory / Jours de Gloire Series (JDG)
- scale = 297 m/hex;
- time = 75 min/GT;
- strength = 200 men/SP.

COMPONENTS
420 full-color die-cut counters.
One 22x34" full-color mapsheet
One 10-sided die
One 24-page Rule Book
2 Player Aid Cards
10986.name: Borodino: Battle of the Moskova, 1812

10987.name: All-in-the-Dice Baseball
10987.description: All-in-the-Dice Baseball is an exciting dice game that simulates all of the action found in professional baseball. There are hits, outs, walks, steals, and erros. Although the results of each play are in the dice, it is the player who determines the strategy to be employed. The game has been statistically perfected so that it is accurate within 2% of professional baseball. Anyone with an understanding of the game of baseball will have endless hours of fun playing the game. AITD can be played with 1 or 2 players. The rules are below in the image section.

10988.name: Bridgehead
10988.description:
"Bridgehead is a game of military tactics a two teams maneuver to build and control a bridge of men across the board between two base positions."

Simple abstract game with a 5x8 position board and 6 pieces per side.

boardgamehonor.12966: 2007 International Gamers Award - General Strategy: Two-players

10989.description: Conhex is a 2-player abstract game in which the winner is the first player to connect his or her assigned sides of a square board (thus the goal is similar to the goal in Twixt.) The board is a pattern of non-regular hexagons with a few non-hexagonal polygons. Players alternate turns placing pieces of their own color on a vertex, and a player can claim a space after placing pieces on at least half the vertices of that space. A description can be found at www.gamerz.net and the game can be played face-to-face or over the internet.
10989.name: ConHex

10990.name: Girl Power
10990.description: Players take turns rolling the dice and collecting tokens representing spirit, loyalty, pride and girl power. The first player to get ten girl power tokens gets to decide to take a solo win, or to continue the game until everyone has ten girl power (a group win). The various spaces and cards all reflect scenarios tending to stress the game's unabashed message of cooperative endeavor.

10991.description:
Only the Ruthless Survive!

Warcraft: The Board Game receives its highly-anticipated expansion! The Warcraft Expansion Set includes a multitude of exciting and flavorful new options for your Warcraft board game experience.

* New rules and components for the sixteen Warcraft heroes
* Random “creep” encounters
* New special race decks
* New specialized board tiles
* New scenarios
* New resource system

For countless hours of brutal fantasy fun!

The Warcraft Expansion Set requires WarCraft: The Board Game to play.

Expands:

WarCraft: The Board Game




Microbadge:
10991.name: WarCraft: The Board Game Expansion Set

10992.name: Zamitar
10992.description:
Zamitar is a chess style game with very 70’s inspired sci-fi acrylic pieces. Each piece has it’s own move, as in a normal chess game. The difference being that a few of the pieces can bounce their moves off the walls.
To win you must take the opponents Space Station piece. The astronaut piece definitely has a “Danger - Will Robinson” (from the old LOST IN SPACE TV Show) feel about it. It is possible to purchase two other forces so you can have a four-player version.

10993.name: Crosshand Poker
10993.description:
Crosshand Poker is a cross between scrabble and poker.
108 (two decks including jokers) traditional playing-card symbol tiles being played on a scrabble-esque grid board inclusive of double and triple scores.

Players draw and update 5 tiles in their rack and play poker 'hands' of tiles branching from the center of the board. Each type of hand has a different score as set out in the. Very much like scrabble except the scores are not on a per-tile basis.
Winner has most points when pool of tiles is depleted.

10995.description:
Game from Strategy & Tactics magazine #180.

Wargame covering the first few weeks of the German offensive in the west, 1914.
10995.name: Reinforce the Right!

10996.description:
Zarcana is a game played with Icehouse Pieces on tarot cards.

"Zarcana is a game of war, journeys, growth, life, and death. Icehouse pieces are your minions, spreading out across a world composed of tarot cards. You move these minions across the board, trying to occupy valuable cards. The board can change, grow and shrink, so be prepared to defend your holdings, invade enemy territory, and colonize new lands. You will also have a hand of cards, drawn from the tarot deck. Each card has a power, and you can make use of the cards you occupy on the board in addition to the cards in your hand. Use them wisely. Whoever occupies the most valuable set of cards on the board will be the winner, when the end of the game is finally declared."

Its rules were included in Icehouse: The Martian Chess Set.

Zarcana was redeveloped into Gnostica.

Zarcana has also been re-implemented by Zark City and Dectana. The former is much simpler and uses a poker deck, while the latter is more complex and uses the Decktet.
10996.name: Zarcana

10997.description:
There's gold in them thar hills!

In Boomtown — a game with auctions, dice, and fun/nasty action cards to play on opponents — you start as a gold digger and try to end as a tycoon. To do this, you must first buy the best mining concessions, hoping to find gold veins. You can also try to become the Mayor of Whiskey River or San Narciso, in order to get a small cut on concessions sales, or build a saloon where lucky prospectors will spend their nuggets in moonshine whiskey. If business is really bad, you can still rely on bank or stagecoach hold-ups to reestablish you. A well placed stick of dynamite can also solve some minor problems.

Piraci features the same gameplay as Boomtown, but with the players now sailing the waters instead of panning them.
10997.name: Boomtown

10998.name: Word Jam
10998.description:
This card game consists of two decks: a deck of topics and a deck of consonants. Both decks are shuffled and five consonants are dealt. The first consonant may not be used by the players in their word but the other consonants may be used and are assigned values of one, two or three. The topic is read aloud and the players must think up a word that fits the topic and uses any or all of the permissible consonants but not the forbidden consonant. The first to think up a word announces it and totals its value. The other players then secretly decide whether anyone else can come up with a higher scoring word. Once the players have voted anyone who thinks a higher scoring can been generated has an additional twenty seconds (a sand timer is included) to announce that word. Points are scored based on who came up with the round's winning word and who voted correctly.

The final round of the game has the players deciding which of two teams to join secretly. The player who comes up with the highest scoring word on each team scores the most points.

The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

10999.name: Abracadabra
10999.description:
From the publisher's website:

The best pupils from the school of magic gather to try out their most powerful spells. But be careful of their clumsy broomstick! A game of forming combinations for apprentice wizards.
